option.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a choice you can make in a particular situation
option.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: There are a number of options available.
This was not the only option open to him.
Teenage mothers often have no option but to (=have no other choice except to) live with their parents.
Another option is to rent somewhere for six months.
one/another option is to do something
a range of options for cutting costs
She had the option of staying for an extra year.
option.translation[0].definitions[1].def: one of the possible choices you can make when using computer software
option.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Select an option from the main menu.
option.translation[0].definitions[2].def: the right to buy or sell something in the future
option.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Connor now owns 302,000 shares and options.
The government has agreed to buy 20 planes, with an option on a further 10.
option.translation[0].definitions[3].def: one of the subjects that you can choose to study at school for an examination, or as part of a course at a college or university
option.translation[0].definitions[4].def: something that is offered in addition to the standard equipment when you buy something new, especially a car
option.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: have an option
At the moment, children have the option of leaving school at 16.
In a situation like this, you have two options.
give/offer somebody an option
Some employees were given the option of retiring early.
Buyers will usually be offered the option of paying in instalments.
choose an option
Fewer women are choosing the option of motherhood.
go for an option
Which option do you think they'll go for?
take (up) an option
America was persuaded not to take up the option of military action.
look at an option
You have to look at every option as your business develops.
limit your options
If you don’t go to college, it may limit your options.
a good/better option
Renting a house may be a better option than buying.
an attractive option
If time is short, taking the car to northern France is an attractive option.
a realistic/real/serious option
I wanted to start my own business but financially it was never a realistic option.
a viable/practical option
Surgery may be a viable option when all else fails.
a popular option
Independent sixth-form colleges are becoming a popular option.
a cheap option
We urgently need to find a cheaper option than oil or gas.
a safe option
A special savings account can be a safe option.
somebody’s preferred option
The new scheme appears to be the airport management’s preferred option.
an easy option
For most people, divorce is never an easy option.
an option is open/available to somebody
Giving a prison sentence is only one of the options open to the judge.
keep/leave your options open
Studying a broad range of subjects helps to keep your options open.
have no/little option but to do something
I had no option but to fire him.
a range of options
The council is considering a range of options for improving the city’s transport system.
option.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a choice between two or more possible things, for example products
option.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Choosing between the available options in mobile phones is very confusing.
option.translation[1].definitions[1].def: something that is offered in addition to the standard equipment when you buy something, especially a car
option.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Passenger airbags are available as standard or as an option on all of its cars.
option.translation[1].definitions[2].def: one of the possible choices you can make when using a computer program
option.translation[1].definitions[3].def: when an organization buys something, the possibility that it will buy more later
option.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: The Spanish air force is due to take 87 of the aircraft, with an option for a further 16.
Shanghai Aviation agreed to buy 26 MD-80s and took options on 15 others.
option.translation[1].definitions[4].def: the right to buy or sell shares, bonds, currencies, or COMMODITIES (=oil, metals, farm products etc) at a particular price within a particular period of time or on a particular date in the future
option.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: Options allow an investor to bet on moves in large amounts of currencies using relatively small stakes.
Each crude-oil options contract entitles its holder to buy or sell the equivalent of 1,000 barrels of oil at a predetermined price.
The stock price fell and the option expired (=came to the end of the period of time when it could be used).
